lg.l: A Lady wise as well as fair
Whose Conscience allway was her care
Thoughtful upon a Point of Moment
Would know the Text as well as coment
Hearing of a grave Divine
She sent to bid him come and dine
Now you must know he was not quite
So grave as to be unpolite
Thought human learning wḍ not lessen
The Dignity of his Profession
And thô you heard the Man discourse
Or preach you'd like him ne'er the worse
He long had bid the Court farewell
Retreating silent to his Cell
Suspected for the Love he bore
To one who sway'd some time before
Which made it more surprizing how
He shoḍ be sent for thither now
The Message told he gapes he stares
And scarce believes his Eyes and Ears
Could not conceive what it should mean
And fain woḍ have it told again
But then the Squire so trim and nice
T'were rude to make him tell it twice
So bow'd was thankful for that honour
And woḍ not fail to wait upon her
His beaver brush'd his Shoes and Gown
Away he trudges into Town
Passes the lower Castle-yard
And now advancing to the Guard
He trembles at the Thoughts of State
Too conscious of a sheepish Gate
His Spirits of a sudden fail'd him
He stop'd & coḍ not tell what ail'd him
What was the Message J receiv'd?
Why certainly the Captain rav'd
To dine with her and come at three
Jmpossible it cannot be
Or maybe J mistook the Word
My Lady it must be my Lord
My Lord's abroad my Lady too
What must the unhappy Doctor do
Is Captain Croachrode here pray? No,
Nay then 'tis time for me to go
Am J awake, or do J dream?
J'm sure he call'd me by my Name
Nam'd me as plain as he could speak
And yet there must be some Mistake
Why what a Jest shou'd J have been
Now? had my Lady been within
What coḍ J've said? J'm mighty glad
She went abroad, she'd thoṭ me mad
The hour of dining now is past,
Well then I'le e'en go home and fast
And since J scap'd being made a Scoff
J think, J'm very faily off
My Lady now returning home
Calls Crochrode, is the Doctor come?
He had not heard of him, pray see
'Tis now a Quarter after three
The Capṭ walks about and searches
Thrô all the rooms, and Courts, & Arches
Examines all the Servants round
Jn vain, no Doctor's to be found
My Lady coḍ not chuse but wonder
Capṭ J fear yov'e made a Blunder
But pray to morrow go at ten
J'll try his Manners once again
Jf Awkerdness be th' effect of Knowledge
My Son shall never see a Colledge
This Capṭ was a Man of reading
And much good Sence as well as breeding
Who loth to blame, or to incense
Said little in his own Defence
Next Day another Message brought
The Doctor frighted at the fault
Js dress'd and stealing thrô the Crowd
Now pale as death then blush'd & bow'd
Panting and fault'ring then hum'd & haw'd
Her Ladyship was gone abroad
The Captn. too he did not know
Whether he ought to stay or go
Beg'd sheḍ forgive him: in Conclusion
The Lady pitying his Confusion
Call'd her good Nature to relieve him
Told him she thoṭ she might believe him
And woḍ not only grant his Suit
But visit him and eat some fruit
Provided at a proper Time
He told the real Truth in Rhyme
'Twas to no purpose to oppose
She'd hear of no Excuse in prose
The Doctor stood not to debate
Glad to compound at any rate
So bowing seemingly comply'd
Tho if he durst he had deny'd
But first resolv'd to shew his Taste
Was too refin'd to give a feast
He'd treat of nothing that was rare
But winding Walks and purer Air
He'd entertain without Expence
Or pride of vain Magnificence
For well he knew to such a Guest
The plainest Meat must be the best
To Stomach cloy'd with costly fare
Simplicity alone is rare
Whilst high & nice and curious Meats
Are really but vulgar Treats
Jnstead of Spoils of Persian Looms
The costly Boast of Regal Rooms
Thoṭ it more courtly and discreet
To scatter roses at her Feet
Roses of riches Dye that shone
With native Lustre like her own
Beauty that needs no Aid of Art
Thrô every Sence to reach the heart
The Gracious Dame althô she knew
All this was much beneath her due
Lik'd every thing at least thoṭ fit
To praise par Maniere d'acquit
But yet thô seeming pleas'd can't bear
The scorching Sun, nor chilling Air
Frighted alike at both Extreams
Jf he displays or hides his Beams
Tho seeming pleas'd at all she sees
Starts at the russling of the Trees
Can scarcely speak for want of breath
Jn half a Walk frighted to Death
The Doctor takes his hint from thence
To vindicate his last Offence
Madm the mighty power of Use
Now strongly pleads in my Excuse
If you unus'd have scarcely Strength
To move this Walk's uncrowded length
Jf startled at a Scene so rude
Thrô long Disuse of Solitude
Jf long confin'd to fires & Screens
You dread the waving of these Greens
Jf trees that neither see nor hear
Nor speak nor walk can give you fear
Jf you who long have breathd yẹ fumes
Of City foggs and crowded Rooms
Do now solicitously shun
The cooler Air or dazling Sun
If Sol's Majesti Eye you flee
Learn hence t'excuse and pity me
Consider what it is to \inserted·(as·alternative?)·bear\·hear
The powder'd Courtier's witty Sneer
To see the important Men of Dress
Deride my Colledge Awkwardness
To be the strutting Cornet's Sport
To run the Gauntlet of the Court
Winning my way by slow approaches
Thrô Crowds of Coxcombs & of Coaches,
From the first fierce cockaded Centry
Quite thrô the tribe of waiting Gentry
To pass so many crowded Stages
And stand the staring of the Pages
And after All to crown my Spleen
Be told you are not to be seen
Or if you be, be forc'd to bear
The Awe of that majestic Air
And can J then be faulty found
Jn dreading this vexat'ous round
Can it be strange if J eschew
A Scene so glaring and so new
Or is he criminal that flies
The living Lustre of yṛ Eyes?
